bioghist.p: Robert E. Spiller (1896-1988) was a scholar of American literary history. He was educated at the University of Pennsylvania, receiving a bachelor's degree in 1917, a master's in 1921 and a Ph.D. in 1924. The majority of Robert Spillerâ€™s teaching career was spent at Penn, where he taught from 1920 to 1967. He was also on the faculty of Swarthmore College from 1921 to 1945. Spiller wrote and edited many books and articles, including Fenimore Cooper: Critic of His Times (1931), The Collected Works of Ralph Waldo Emerson, and Milestones in American Literary History (1977). He was one of the editors of the Literary History of the United States series.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes materials related to Spiller's teaching, scholarship and other professional and personal activities. Materials about research projects include files on James Fenimore Cooper, including photostat copies of letters from and about Cooper, photographs of people and places, a reel of film and engravings; reprints by Spiller and others; and files on Ralph Waldo Emerson, including minutes, correspondence, work schedules and timetables, drafts of notes on Emerson's essays, and other research materials. Materials related to the Literary History of the United States include minutes, correspondence, outlines and instructions to authors, chapter drafts and proofs, bibliography, financial records, publicity information and reviews. Materials related to Spiller's teaching and scholarship include correspondence; manuscripts and proofs of books, chapters, essays and addresses, including Late Harvest and Milestones in American Literary History; reviews of his writings; and University of Pennsylvania English Department records, including minutes, reports, newsletters, bulletins, and some correspondence. There are also early writings (plays, poetry, prose); letters to parents from school and from abroad, 1914-1929; postcards; family photographs; address books and appointment books; an undated manuscript (appears to be 18th century) in a mixture of Latin and Greek; a typescript of an interview with Spiller in 1983; and records of various professional activities, including seminars and lectures abroad, MLA committees, Guggenheim Fellowship, seminars at Swarthmore, American Council of Learned Societies projects, and a Nobel symposium.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
